title: 106_hr3013
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alaska Native Claims Technical Amendments Act of 1999". Section 7(h)(1)(C)(iii) is amended to include provisions regarding adopted-out descendants. SEC. 3. RELATION TO CIVIL RIGHTS ACT OF 1964. Amends Section 29(g) of the Act to exclude certain entities from the definition of 'employer'. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF SETTLEMENT TRUST. Amends Section 3(t)(2) to specify beneficiaries. SEC. 5. ALASKA NATIVE VETERANS. Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to allow for the selection of allotments only from specific types of lands. This includes lands that were vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved when the eligible person first used and occupied them. The amendment to Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows for the selection of allotments from lands in the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska that were used and occupied, as well as lands that were not vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved when first used but became so either before or after December 18, 1971. The amendment to Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act includes changes such as inserting specific phrases, striking certain terms, and adding qualifiers to different subsections. The amendment to Section 41 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act involves various changes, including inserting phrases, striking terms, and adding qualifiers to different subsections. In subsection (b)(2), amendments are made to replace "subsection (b)(1)" with "paragraph (1)" and to strike "if, during" and following text up to "prisoner of war." with "under this section." In subsection (b)(3), changes include adding "previously applied for the same allotment," after "No person who received an allotment," inserting "application" after "pending allotment," replacing "receive" with "apply for," and adding a clause regarding personal representatives of an estate. In subsection (e), further modifications are made. In subsection (e), amendments include changes to references, rules, and approval of allotments within a specified timeframe by the Secretary in accordance with the Alaska Native Claims Technical Amendments Act of 1999. The Act of May 17, 1906 outlines the process for Native allotment applications, including notification to the State and interested parties, protest filing within 12 months, and adjudication based on applicable laws. The Act of May 17, 1906 governs Native allotment applications, with provisions for protests by Native Corporations or the State regarding land entitlement or access rights. The Act of May 17, 1906 governs Native allotment applications, with provisions for protests regarding land entitlement or access rights. Protests can be filed if there are concerns about access, entitlement to the land, improvements claimed on the land, or communal use of the land. Approval procedures are initiated after 18 months. Upon expiration of the 18-month application period, the Secretary will approve the application if no protest is filed, or adjudicate the legal sufficiency of any protest filed. If the protest is deemed legally insufficient, the application will be approved. If the protest is valid, a final decision will be issued closing the application. SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY OF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE RESTRICTIONS. Section 22(g) of the Act is amended by striking ``Notwithstanding'' and all that follows through ``of such Refuge.''. SEC. 7. ELIM NATIVE CORPORATION LAND RESTORATION. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended by adding a new section for Elim Native Corporation land restoration. The Congress finds that approximately 350,000 acres of land were withdrawn in 1917 for the use of the United States Bureau of Education and the Natives of Indigenous Alaskan race, including the Norton Bay Reservation set aside for the benefit of the Native inhabitants of Elim, Alaska. In 1929, 50,000 acres were deleted from the Reservation without the consent of the Native residents, violating the Act of March 3, 1927. Minimal consultation was conducted by the United States Government with the inhabitants. The lands were deleted from the Reservation for the benefit of others without offering restoration to the original Reservation, causing deep concern and frustration among the indigenous people of Elim. This unresolved issue continues to be a source of great loss for the shareholders of the Elim Native Corporation and their descendants. The lands deleted from the Norton Bay Reservation in 1929, meant for the Village of Elim, should be replaced with 50,000 acres for the Elim Native Corporation. These lands are temporarily withdrawn for 2 years for selection by the Corporation within a designated area near Elim, Alaska. The Elim Native Corporation is authorized to select and receive title to 50,000 acres of lands to replace those deleted from the Norton Bay Reservation. The lands are temporarily withdrawn for 2 years for selection by the Corporation near Elim, Alaska. The Elim Native Corporation is authorized to select up to 60,000 acres of land adjacent to U.S. Survey No. 2548 in Alaska. The selection must be compact, contiguous, and prioritized, remaining withdrawn until conveyed or full entitlement is achieved. The Elim Native Corporation is authorized to select up to 60,000 acres of land in Alaska, subject to valid existing rights. Easements for public benefit will be reserved by the Bureau of Land Management in the conveyance to the Corporation. The Elim Native Corporation is authorized to select up to 60,000 acres of land in Alaska, with the Bureau of Land Management reserving easements for public benefit. Final selection and conveyance of lands to the Corporation will satisfy their land entitlements and extinguish the Norton Bay Reservation. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF LIABILITY FOR CONTAMINATION. This section clarifies that individuals acquiring land under this Act will not be held liable for contamination on the land unless they were directly responsible for it.
